title: Stagnant manufacturing highlights challenge for Britain's makers
text:

Tue, Sep 22, 2015, 13:40 BST - UK Markets close in 2 hrs 50 mins Stagnant manufacturing highlights challenge for Britain's makers By Szu Ping Chan | Telegraph – 16 minutes ago Print 
Strong pound hampers factory output as manufacturing stalls in September and export orders fall to six month low, CBI survey shows 
UK factory output stalled for the first time in two and a half years in September as manufacturers struggled with the strong pound. 
The Confederation of British Industry's (CBI) latest industrial trends survey showed output volumes were stagnant in the three months to September, ending a run of growth that stretched back to February 2013. 
Britain's biggest business group described export demand as Britain's "weak link", as order volumes fell to a six-month low. 
The survey showed 26pc of the 491 businesses surveyed said output grew in the three months to September, while 25pc said output fell. 
The rounded balance of zero was slightly below the long-run average of 3pc and well below last month's positive reading of 14pc. 
“Exports are the missing link in the UK recovery at the moment, with the strong pound squeezing manufacturers’ margins, even though lower commodity prices are helping to ease cost pressures," said Rain Newton-Smith, the CBI's director of economics. 
“Meanwhile manufacturers will have an eye on China’s slowdown and its effect on neighbouring markets." 
The poll also showed manufacturers were more optimistic about output over the next three months, with a balance of 9pc of companies expecting growth in the final quarter of 2015. 
Ms Newton Smith urged the Government to do more to support the manufacturing sector in the Comprehensive Spending Review and Autumn Statement on November 25. Manufacturing drives around 10pc of UK gross domestic output. 
The survey also showed businesses expect average prices to fall further in the next quarter, to the greatest extent since August 2009.
